Comm-Shanghai-1909.name: Shanghai Opium Commission, 1909
Comm-Shanghai-1909.description: First international meeting on opium trade, led to 1912 Hague Convention.

Treaty-Hague-1912.name: International Opium Convention (Hague, 1912)
Treaty-Hague-1912.description: First international drug control treaty restricting opium, morphine, cocaine, and heroin to medical use.
Treaty-Hague-1912.in_force: 28 June 1919 (globally incorporated into Treaty of Versailles)

Treaty-Geneva-1925a.name: Convention concerning the Manufacture of, Internal Trade in, and Use of Prepared Opium (Geneva, 1925)
Treaty-Geneva-1925a.description: Controlled prepared opium for smoking, focused on Far Eastern territories.

Treaty-Geneva-1925b.name: International Convention relating to Dangerous Drugs (Geneva, 1925)
Treaty-Geneva-1925b.description: Expanded drug controls beyond opium to include other narcotic substances.

Treaty-Geneva-1931.name: Convention for Limiting the Manufacture and Regulating the Distribution of Narcotic Drugs (Geneva, 1931)
Treaty-Geneva-1931.description: Introduced statistical control system and manufacturing limits. Established Permanent Central Opium Board.

Treaty-Geneva-1936.name: Convention of 1936 for the Suppression of the Illicit Traffic in Dangerous Drugs
Treaty-Geneva-1936.description: First treaty criminalizing drug trafficking as international crime, led by precursor to INTERPOL.

Treaty-LakeSuccess-1946.name: Lake Success Protocol 1946
Treaty-LakeSuccess-1946.description: Transferred drug control functions from League of Nations to United Nations after WWII.

Treaty-Paris-1948.name: Protocol bringing under International Control Drugs Outside of the Scope of the 1931 Convention
Treaty-Paris-1948.description: Extended international control to drugs outside 1931 Convention. Established Commission on Narcotic Drugs.

Treaty-UN-1961.name: UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs (1961)
Treaty-UN-1961.description: Consolidated all previous treaties. Broadened scope to cannabis, established INCB, limits use to medical/scientific purposes.

Treaty-OAS-1971.name: Inter-American Convention on the Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (1971)
Treaty-OAS-1971.description: Regional OAS treaty for combating illicit drug trafficking in the Americas.

Treaty-Vienna-1971.name: Vienna Convention on Psychotropic Substances (1971)
Treaty-Vienna-1971.description: Extended control to psychotropic substances: amphetamines, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, psychedelics. Four schedules.

Treaty-UN-1972.name: Protocol amending the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961
Treaty-UN-1972.description: Expanded INCB role regarding illicit production, use, and trafficking in narcotic drugs.

Treaty-CAN-1985.name: Andean Community Decision 391 (1985)
Treaty-CAN-1985.description: Established common rules for drug control and cooperation among Andean countries.

Treaty-UN-1988.name: UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (1988)
Treaty-UN-1988.description: Comprehensive measures against trafficking including money laundering, precursor chemicals, international cooperation.

Treaty-EU-2004.name: Council Framework Decision 2004/757/JHA
Treaty-EU-2004.description: EU framework establishing minimum criminal penalties for illicit drug trafficking.

Framework-CAN.name: CAN Plan of Action on Drugs
Framework-CAN.description: Strategic framework for CAN members to coordinate drug policies, development programs, regional cooperation.

Body-OpiumCommittee.name: Opium Advisory Committee
Body-OpiumCommittee.description: League of Nations advisory body on opium issues, predecessor to later UN drug control bodies.

Body-PCOB.name: Permanent Central Opium Board (PCOB)
Body-PCOB.description: League of Nations body monitoring drug manufacturing and trade statistics, merged into INCB in 1968.

Body-CND.name: Commission on Narcotic Drugs
Body-CND.description: UN policy-making body for international drug control, established 1946.

Body-CNB.name: Commission on Narcotics Board
Body-CNB.description: UN body that merged with PCOB in 1968 to form INCB.

Body-WHO.name: World Health Organization (WHO)
Body-WHO.description: UN specialized agency providing scientific assessments of drugs for international scheduling decisions.

Body-OAS.name: Organization of American States (OAS)
Body-OAS.description: Regional organization of American states coordinating policy including drug control through CICAD.

Body-INCB.name: International Narcotics Control Board (INCB)
Body-INCB.description: Independent UN body monitoring treaty compliance, formed 1968 from merger of PCOB and Drug Supervisory Body.

Body-CAN.name: Comunidad Andina de Naciones (CAN)
Body-CAN.description: South American trade bloc coordinating regional drug policy among member states.
Body-CAN.in_force: 1969 (as Andean Pact), 1997 (as CAN per Trujillo Protocol)

Body-EuropeanCouncil.name: European Council
Body-EuropeanCouncil.description: EU institution providing political direction and priorities, including drug policy coordination.

Body-CICAD.name: Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD)
Body-CICAD.description: OAS commission strengthening member capacity to prevent and treat drug abuse and combat trafficking.

Body-EMCDDA.name: European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA)
Body-EMCDDA.description: EU agency providing factual data and analysis on drugs and drug addiction.

Body-UNODC.name: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
Body-UNODC.description: UN office leading global fight against illicit drugs and crime through research, guidance, and field support.

PE-DL11005-1949.name: Criminal Code Reform - Decreto Ley 11005 (Peru)
PE-DL11005-1949.description: Reformed criminal code increasing penalties for drug trafficking and possession offenses.

PE-Treaty-1964.name: Peru Ratification of Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs of 1961
PE-Treaty-1964.description: Peru's ratification of 1961 UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs.

PE-DL22095-1978.name: Law for the Suppression of Illegal Drug Trafficking - Decreto Ley 22095 (Peru)
PE-DL22095-1978.description: Comprehensive drug law establishing severe penalties for trafficking, cultivation, possession of coca and other drugs.

PE-Treaty-1980.name: Peru Ratification of Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971
PE-Treaty-1980.description: Peru's ratification of UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances extending control to psychotropic substances.

PE-DL122-1981.name: Amendment to Drug Trafficking Law - Decreto Legislativo 122 (Peru)
PE-DL122-1981.description: Modified drug trafficking penalties, introduced reduced sentences for small quantities and personal addiction.

PE-Treaty-1990.name: Peru Ratification of Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances of 1988
PE-Treaty-1990.description: Peru's ratification of 1988 UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

PE-CriminalCode-1991.name: Criminal Code (Peru)
PE-CriminalCode-1991.description: Maintained harsh trafficking penalties, removed criminal sanctions for personal drug use in small amounts.

PE-DL824-1996.name: Law to Fight Illicit Drug Trafficking - Decreto Legislativo 824 (Peru)
PE-DL824-1996.description: Declared drug fight national interest priority, strengthened penalties and enforcement mechanisms.

PE-Regulation-2001.name: Regulation of Controlled Narcotic and Psychotropic Substances (Peru)
PE-Regulation-2001.description: Established controls over narcotic and psychotropic substances including licensing and monitoring.

PE-DL1126-2012.name: Law of Controlled Substances used in Illicit Drugs - Decreto Legislativo 1126 (Peru)
PE-DL1126-2012.description: Controlled chemical inputs, machinery, and equipment used in illicit drug production.

PE-DL1241-2015.name: Law to Strengthen Suppression of Illegal Drug Trafficking - Decreto Legislativo 1241 (Peru)
PE-DL1241-2015.description: Enhanced police capacity, created Drug Information System, criminalized illegal coca replanting (3-8 years).

US-Harrison-1914.name: Harrison Narcotics Tax Act (United States)
US-Harrison-1914.description: First comprehensive US drug law, regulated and taxed production, importation, distribution of opiates and coca products.

US-Marihuana-1937.name: Marihuana Tax Act (United States)
US-Marihuana-1937.description: First federal cannabis regulation, effectively prohibited marijuana through prohibitive taxation.

US-Boggs-1951.name: Boggs Act (United States)
US-Boggs-1951.description: Established mandatory minimum sentences for drug convictions. First offense cannabis: 2-10 years, up to $20,000 fine.

US-Narcotics-1956.name: Narcotic Control Act (United States)
US-Narcotics-1956.description: Increased mandatory minimums: 5 years first offense, 10 years subsequent. Prohibited suspended sentences for many offenses.

US-CSA-1970.name: Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act / Controlled Substances Act (United States)
US-CSA-1970.description: Consolidated federal drug laws. Established five schedules classifying drugs by medical use and abuse potential.

US-AntiDrug-1986.name: Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986 (United States)
US-AntiDrug-1986.description: Mandatory minimums with 100:1 crack/powder cocaine disparity. Criminalized money laundering, increased trafficking penalties.

US-AntiDrug-1988.name: Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 (United States)
US-AntiDrug-1988.description: Created Drug Czar office, extended mandatory minimums to conspiracy/attempt, authorized $2.8 billion for drug control.

US-Treaty-1980.name: US Ratification of the Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971
US-Treaty-1980.description: Ratified the UN Vienna Convention on Psychotropic Substances, presenting a reservation for traditional use of Peyote.
